definition.value: A pattern of signs and symptoms that typically co-occur.

name: syndrome
body: A pattern of signs and symptoms that typically co-occur.

definition.value: Mild cognitive impairment is the occurence of one or more cognitive deficits [visual spatial, attention, orientation, executive function, functional] that are beyond those expected based on the age and education of the individual, but which are not significant enough to interfere with their daily activities.  It is typically the result of _________ .

editor note.value:
Remove last sentence of defintion. "Typically" doesn't ontologize well. Nor do fill-in-the-blanks ;-)

Mark Jensen

Suggest removing 'mild' from label. Dementia is not a type of mild cognitive impairment. A syndrome of cognitive impairment makes more sense and tracks far better with reality. 

A diagnosis of MCI can be non-pathological, ie- normal ageing related cognitive decline.

Mark Jensen

children.name: mild cognitive impairment
children.body: Mild cognitive impairment is the occurence of one or more cognitive deficits [visual spatial, attention, orientation, executive function, functional] that are beyond those expected based on the age and education of the individual, but which are not significant enough to interfere with their daily activities.  It is typically the result of _________ .

definition.value:
Dementia is the co-occurence of cognitive deficits in at least two domains [memory, visual spatial, attention, orientation, executive function, functional] resulting in a decline of previous functioning.  It typically results from the realization of a dementia disease.

*** TEMPLATE FOR SYNDROME DEFINITIONS??? ***

editor note.value:
I think this is incorrect. First it should be defined wrt its parent. I don't think the parent of "dementia syndrome" will turn out to be "MCI syndrome". Admittedly that will depend on the specifics to the aggreed upon definitions. Currently they are both in need or refinement.
Second, the definition is too Alzheimer-centric, and I believe would rule out other instances of dementia. Dementia does not typically result from a "dementia disease". Even if true, whatever “typical” means, that assertion is informative, not explanatory — i.e., it belongs in an elucidation not the definition.  

Mark Jensen

children.name: dementia
children.body:
Dementia is the co-occurence of cognitive deficits in at least two domains [memory, visual spatial, attention, orientation, executive function, functional] resulting in a decline of previous functioning.  It typically results from the realization of a dementia disease.

*** TEMPLATE FOR SYNDROME DEFINITIONS??? ***

definition.value: Typical Alzheimers syndrome is the insidious onset of dementia syndrome that is characterized by episodic memory loss.  It typically results from the realization of Alzheimers disease.

children.name: typical Alzheimers syndrome
children.body: Typical Alzheimers syndrome is the insidious onset of dementia syndrome that is characterized by episodic memory loss.  It typically results from the realization of Alzheimers disease.

definition.value: Atypical Alzheimers syndrome is the insidious onset of dementia syndrome that is typically characterized by the absence of episodic memory loss.  It typically results from the realization of either frontal variant of Alzheimers disease, logopenic aphasia, posterior cortical atrophy, or primary progressive nonfluent aphasia.

children.name: atypical Alzheimers syndrome
children.body: Atypical Alzheimers syndrome is the insidious onset of dementia syndrome that is typically characterized by the absence of episodic memory loss.  It typically results from the realization of either frontal variant of Alzheimers disease, logopenic aphasia, posterior cortical atrophy, or primary progressive nonfluent aphasia.

definition.value: Parkinsonism is the co-occurence of any combination of the classical features of Parkinson's disease [tremor, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, postural instability].  It typically results from the realization of either Parkinsons disease, progressive supranuclear palsy, or multiple system atrophy.

children.name: Parkinsonism
children.body: Parkinsonism is the co-occurence of any combination of the classical features of Parkinson's disease [tremor, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, postural instability].  It typically results from the realization of either Parkinsons disease, progressive supranuclear palsy, or multiple system atrophy.

definition.value: Parkinson plus syndrome is the co-occurence of any combination of the classical features of Parkinsons disease [tremor, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, postural instability] with additional features [supranuclear palsy, paralysis of downward gaze, autonomic dysfunction, additional cortical signs, etc] that distinguishes it from simple idiopathic Parkinsons disease.  It typically results from the realization of either multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, corticobasal degeneration, or Lewy body dementia.

children.name: Parkinson plus syndrome
children.body: Parkinson plus syndrome is the co-occurence of any combination of the classical features of Parkinsons disease [tremor, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, postural instability] with additional features [supranuclear palsy, paralysis of downward gaze, autonomic dysfunction, additional cortical signs, etc] that distinguishes it from simple idiopathic Parkinsons disease.  It typically results from the realization of either multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, corticobasal degeneration, or Lewy body dementia.

definition.value: Epilepsy is the occurence of multiple seizures over the course of an individual's life.

children.name: epilepsy
children.body: Epilepsy is the occurence of multiple seizures over the course of an individual's life.
